'''Leroy Carr''' (March 27, 1905 – April 29, 1935)<ref name="amg">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p304/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography]</ref>  was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[singer]], [[songwriter]] and [[pianist]], who developed a laid-back, [[crooning]] technique and whose popularity and style influenced such [[musician|artists]] as [[Nat King Cole]] and [[Ray Charles]]. He first became famous for "[[How Long, How Long Blues]]" on [[Vocalion Records]] in 1928.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 52–53
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Carr was born in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], but raised in Indianapolis, Indiana. Although his recording career was cut short by an early death, Carr left behind a large body of work.<ref name="russell"/> Some of his most famous songs include "Blues Before Sunrise" (1932), "Midnight Hour Blues" (1932), and "Hurry Down Sunshine" (1934).  He had a long-time partnership with guitarist [[Scrapper Blackwell]]. His light bluesy piano combined with Blackwell's melodic jazz guitar worked to attract a sophisticated black audience. Carr's vocal style moved blues singing toward an urban sophistication, influencing such singers as [[T-Bone Walker]], [[Charles Brown (musician)|Charles Brown]], [[Amos Milburn]], [[Jimmy Witherspoon]], [[Ray Charles]] among others.<ref name="shaw">{{cite book
| first= Arnold
| last= Shaw
| year= 1978
| title= Honkers and Shouters
| edition= 
| publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company 
| location= New York
| pages= 8–9
| isbn= 0-02-061740-2}}</ref> 

[[Count Basie]] and [[Jimmy Rushing]] used some of Carr's songs and Basie's band shows the influence of Carr's piano style.<ref name="keil">{{cite book
| first= Charles
| last= Keil
| year=1991 
| title= Urban Blues
| edition= 
| publisher= University of Chicago Press
| location=Chicago, IL
| pages= 65–67, 107
| isbn= 0-226-42960-1 }}</ref>

His music has been [[cover version|covered]] by notable artists such as [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Big Bill Broonzy]], [[Moon Mullican]], [[Champion Jack Dupree]], [[Lonnie Donegan]] and [[Memphis Slim]].

Carr was an alcoholic in private, and died of [[nephritis]] shortly after his thirtieth birthday.<ref name=Larkin>{{cite web|last=Larkin|first=Colin|title=Carr, Leroy|work=Encyclopedia of Popular Music|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref>
